items.title:
The Core Model: Designing Inside Out for Better Results
A simple method for thinking deeply about important...

object.content:
The Core Model: Designing Inside Out for Better Results
A simple method for thinking deeply about important pages. It can be very useful in highlighting research findings.﻿

attachments.displayName: The Core Model: Designing Inside Out for Better Results
attachments.content: We’ve all fallen into territorial arguments about what content belongs on a site’s homepage. It’s the most important part of your website, after all—or is it? Ida Aalen shows us how to circumvent these turf wars with the Core Model approach, starting with a workshop to get everyone on the same page about what really counts as important—to your users. By identifying the core elements of your website as a team, you’ll make those smaller decisions a...

items.title: I find it annoying to open PDF files to look for specific information. Especially when the information...

object.content:
I find it annoying to open PDF files to look for specific information. Especially when the information ought to be on the web in the first place. Imagine opening a PDF file to look for a specific branch location. Not only I have to open the file but also have to scroll the long document to find the branch address. Messy! Here's a solution to this mess.
http://www.pebbleroad.com/perspectives/move-data-tables-from-pdf-to-web﻿

attachments.displayName: Move data tables from PDF to the web
attachments.content: A simple way to move data tables stuck in PDF files to the web so that users can easily browse and search for specific information.

Featuring Louis Zulli Jr, our Platinum award winner from Lakewood High School, there were just under 500 registrations for the event. In addition to a live tour given by Lou, the webinar focused on two key themes: the power of design thinking, and innovation in …

items.title: UX for the enterprise is finally getting attention. This A List Apart article talks about the opportunities...

object.content:
UX for the enterprise is finally getting attention. This A List Apart article talks about the opportunities and the challenges of working with large organisations.
http://alistapart.com/article/ux-for-the-enterprise
Now, there is even a conference dedicated to it in 2015.
http://enterpriseux.net/﻿

attachments.content: Enterprise UX often involves navigating cumbersome processes, ancient technology, and clients skeptical of design’s value. Yet Fortune 500 companies are often the ones most in need of well-designed internal tools. Jordan Koschei takes us through common problems lurking in global organizations—and how we can improve people’s lives by giving internal tools the same attention as consumer interfaces.

items.title: Maish presented “Designing the search experience” for the IxDA community in Singapore. Get the deck ...

object.content:
Maish presented “Designing the search experience” for the IxDA community in Singapore. Get the deck on Slideshare. 
http://www.slideshare.net/maish/designing-the-search-experience-42026607﻿

attachments.content: Search is not just the place your users go to when they are lost or have something specific to find. It is also a place where your users go to to have a conversation about their needs. Avinash Kaushik remind us that search is the only place that gets used more than 10% of the time. So, how are we designing this conversation? In this presenation for the IXDA Singapore community, I share a framework to design the search experience.

items.title: We know that having structured content in PDF is not usable. What can one do? Here’s what we did: we...

object.content:
We know that having structured content in PDF is not usable. What can one do? Here’s what we did: we scraped the data from the PDF, cleaned it up and moved it to Google Fusion Tables. We used the API to display the content on a web page in table form, along with search functionality! Take a look at the outcome: http://www.mom.gov.sg/beta/wsh-training/find-training-provider.html
Interested? We will release the code soon.﻿

items.title: Responsive Images in Practice

object.content: Responsive Images in Practice﻿

attachments.content: When we design responsively, our content elegantly and efficiently flows into any device. All of our content, that is, except images. For years, we’ve catered to users with the highest-resolution screens by sending giant images to everyone. No longer. Eric Portis takes us through the new picture element and other attributes to let us mark up multiple, alternate sources. Find out how to use responsive images now: send the best image for each conte...
